titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of Connie Nappier Jr. at the Veterans History Project
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Witt Meesangnil
titlestmt.sponsor: CCSU Veterans History Project is an official partner with The Veterans History Project of the American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-01-04T17:31-0500

did.abstract: This collection details experience of Connie Nappier Jr. during World War II. He served as the "Tuskegee Airmen", the first African American military aviators in the United States armed forces. The collection contains personal service records, military correspondence, publications about Tuskegee Airmen, photographs, and an oral history interview.
did.physloc: Center for Public Policy and Social Research (CPPSR) 207 DiLoreto Hall, Central Connecticut State University (CCSU) 1615 Stanley St. New Britain, CT 06050

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Connie Nappier, Jr. enlisted in the U.S. Army Air Corps after graduating high school in 1943. He wanted to be part of the Tuskegee Experiment, the program the Air Corps had set up to train African American fighter pilots. After endured grueling ground training at Tuskegee Air Field, he and a few other soldiers were informed that their services were needed as bombardier navigators. He and group of others from Tuskegee Air Field were sent to Midland, Texas to complete the flight and ground training as bombardier navigators. It was during this time that Nappier was given his "wings", and made an officer, and the 477th medium bomb group was formed, which was a segregated bomb group. Nappier was a Flight Officer in the 477th, when the soldiers were transferred to Freeman Field in Indiana. At Freeman Field, 101 officers of the 477th Bomb Group were arrested for disobeying the Jim Crow laws that were established by Col. Selway, the base's commanding officer. Col. Selway had the men arrested, Nappier among them, and sent to the stockade at Goodman Field in Kentucky. It wasn't until an order was received from President Truman that the officers were released. Nappier then returned to Tuskegee Air Field to finish his pilot training. He had dreamed of becoming a pilot since childhood. He was part of the 46D class, which was the last pilot class trained at Tuskegee. Unfortunately, the war ended, and the pilots' training was not completed. Nappier was discharged from the Air Corps, and he returned home to Hartford, Ct, where he used the G.I. Bill to complete his education as an architect. In 2007, after this interview was recorded, Nappier received the Congressional Gold Medal in Washington, D.C. alongside other veterans from Tuskegee Air Field.

userestrict.p: For permission to publish please contact Central Connecticut State University’s Center for Public Policy and Social Research at (860) 832-2976.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: All manuscripts and photographs donated were digitized and digitally preserved. The donor retained all original manuscripts and photographs.

altformavail.p: An online exhibition of this veteran's papers can be accessed at project's website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Tuskegee Airmen were forced to operate as segregated units and not allowed to train or fight alongside their white fellow countrymen. To identify themselves they painted the tails of their aircraft red, thus becoming the "Red Tails". The Tuskegee Airmen "Red Tails" carried their hopes and dreams of equality for themselves and their thirteen million African American countrymen into battle. Source: The CAF Red Tail Project. http://www.redtail.org/airmen.html
